item.description:
Join us for another FREE classical music concert at the New England Conservatory of Music!

Tonight, Maestro Hugh Wolff, the NEC's Director of Orchestras, conducts Dmitri Shostakovich's 1st symphony, Beethoven's 4th piano concerto, (with soloist Nino Bakradze) and Mozart's famous Symphony No. 35 (the "Haffner.")  For more information on this concert, visit http://necmusic.edu/nec-philharmonia-wolff.

This concert is sure to be popular and crowded, as they are playing well known works and Wolff is conducting, so let's meet up at 7:15pm, so the group has a chance to get good seats and socialize before the concert. (Doors to the Hall will open at 7:30.)  We usually end up sitting in left-middle section of the balcony, since this affords a good view of the entire orchestra, is open to the ceiling, and is easy to describe and find, it is relatively easy to grab a large block of seats there, and affords an excellent view of the pianist if listening to a piano concerto.

Note: Due to Meetup's terrible decision to remove the Maybe option (write to Meetup here if you want to register your displeasure with that!), please indicate whether you are a Maybe in your Yes RSVP, and try to update your RSVP if you're not coming. 

Directions to Jordan Hall:
The hall is located at the corner of Huntington and Gainsborough streets, about a block south of the Symphony T stop on the Green Line. Look for the building with the YMCA sign on top of it--it's near that building. The main entrance is reached from Gainsborough Street.

This evening's program will include:

  • Mozart Symphony No. 35 in D Major ("Haffner"), K.385 (listen to the 1st movement)
  • Beethoven Piano Concerto No. 4 in G Major, Op. 58 (listen to the rondo here)
  • Shostakovich Symphony No. 1 in F Minor, Op. 10 (listen to the 1st movement here)
item.how_to_find_us: I will stand in the lobby until 7:45, after which I will join the group upstairs in the left-middle balcony section if its open, or in the back center floor section if it's not.
item.name: NEC Classical Spring Concert Series: Wolff & Shostakovich, Mozart, Beethoven
